questions.text:
A 60-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of nausea, headache, and generalized fatigue for 2 days. He has not vomited. He was diagnosed with small cell lung cancer and liver metastases around 3 months ago and is currently receiving chemotherapy with cisplatin and etoposide. His last chemotherapy cycle ended one week ago. He has chronic obstructive lung disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include insulin and a salmeterol-fluticasone inhaler. He appears malnourished. He is oriented to time, place, and person. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 13/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mm Hg. There is no edema. Examination shows decreased breath sounds over the left lung. Cardiac examination shows an S4. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Neurological examination shows no focal findings. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11.6 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4300/mm3



Platelet count
146,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

125 mEq/L


 Cl−

105 mEq/L


 K+

4.5 mEq/L


 HCO3−

24 mEq/L


 Glucose
225 mg/dL


 Total bilirubin
1.1 mg/dL


 Alkaline phosphatase
110 U/L


 AST
78 U/L


 ALT
90 U/L


Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following set of laboratory findings?



Serum osmolality
Urine osmolality
Urinary sodium excretion



A
220 mOsm/kg H2O
130 mOsm/kg H2O
10 mEq/L


B
269 mOsm/kg H2O
369 mOsm/kg H2O
82 mEq/L


C
255 mOsm/kg H2O
45 mOsm/kg H2O
12 mEq/L


D
222 mOsm/kg H2O
490 mOsm/kg H2O
10 mEq/L


E
310 mOsm/kg H2O
420 mOsm/kg H2O
16 mEq/L
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This is the expected laboratory finding in patients with hypervolemic hyponatremia (e.g., due to cirrhosis or congestive heart failure). Despite hypervolemia, effective circulating volume is diminished (from low cardiac output in congestive heart failure or splanchnic vasodilation in cirrhosis), causing the kidneys to incorrectly detect a state of hypovolemia. Subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and secretion of antidiuretic hormone leads to a net effect of reabsorption of a greater amount of free water than sodium, resulting in hyponatremia. Although this patient does have signs of liver damage (likely from metastasis and cisplatin therapy), these do not suggest cirrhosis (only mildly elevated liver enzymes, absence of ascites).

B) CORRECT:

SIADH will result in free water reabsorption in the kidneys by increasing aquaporins in the distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts. Excess free water retention causes low serum osmolality (< 280 mOsm/kg) and hyponatremia (< 135 mEq/L), as well as concentrated urine (> 100 mOsm/kg). Since the patient is euvolemic and therefore does not retain sodium through activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, there will be normal to high urine sodium excretion (> 20–30 mEq/L).
Image Description:

FENa: fractional excretion of sodium
SIADH: syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
TURP: transurethral resection of the prostate
UNa: urine sodium
UOsm: urine osmolality

C) INCORRECT:

These would be the expected laboratory results in primary polydipsia. An excess in free water intake will lower serum osmolality and cause a compensatory reduction in the secretion of antidiuretic hormone, which will dilute urine to a maximum (reducing urine osmolality) to excrete excess fluid. Urine sodium excretion will remain low, however, as the kidneys will respond to reduced serum osmolality by reabsorbing sodium. This patient does not have a history of drinking excessive amounts of fluid, making these findings unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

These would be the expected laboratory findings in patients with extrarenal fluid loss (e.g., vomiting, diarrhea), indicating hypovolemic hyponatremia. Loss of sodium and free water will decrease effective circulating volume and cause secretion of antidiuretic hormone and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Therefore, urinary sodium excretion is decreased and osmolality is elevated as the kidneys work to reabsorb free water and sodium from the urine. The net effect is retention of more free water than sodium, resulting in hyponatremia. As the patient has not had any vomiting or diarrhea, this diagnosis is unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

These would be the expected laboratory results in hypertonic hyponatremia (e.g., due to hyperglycemia). In hyperglycemia, excess glucose will increase the serum osmolality and cause hyponatremia through water shift (osmosis) from the intracellular to the extracellular space (serum sodium levels decrease by 1.6 points for each 100 mg/dL glucose above normal). The actual sodium content does not change. Glucose excreted in the urine will cause elevated urine osmolality and urine sodium excretion will be low due to likely hypovolemia from osmotic diuresis and subsequent activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. Although this patient does have elevated glucose levels (225 mg/dL), this does not account for the degree of his hyponatremia.
questions.hint: Small cell lung cancer is commonly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH). Nausea, headache, and fatigue in this patient are likely due to the hyponatremia caused by this paraneoplastic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because of increasing confusion and generalized fatigue over the past week. During this period, she has had muscle cramps, headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Six days ago, she underwent resection of a parasagittal meningioma. She tolerated the procedure well without complications and was discharged two days ago. She has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension. Current medications include oxycodone, acetaminophen, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. She is oriented only to person and place. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Serum



 Na+

126 mEq/L


 K+

3.6 mEq/L


 Cl-

107 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dL


 Glucose
87 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


 Osmolality

263 mOsmol/kg H2O


Urine



 Osmolality

523 mOsmol/kg H2O


 Sodium

44 mEq/L


Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebral salt wasting syndrome, which may occur in patients after neurosurgical procedures, is a poorly understood cause of hypovolemic, hypotonic hyponatremia. Patients with cerebral salt wasting syndrome have a low serum osmolality, as seen here, but also present with symptoms of hypovolemia (e.g., hypotension, tachycardia) and paradoxical polyuria.

B) CORRECT:

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) can occur following injury to the CNS and is an important differential diagnosis to consider for any neurosurgery patient presenting with hyponatremia. SIADH causes euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia. Increased activity of antidiuretic hormone decreases free-water clearance, which results in a low serum osmolality (< 280 mOsmol/kg H2O), and inappropriately concentrated urine (> 100 mOsmol/kg H2O). Since patients with SIADH are typically euvolemic and therefore do not retain sodium through activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, there will be normal to high urine sodium excretion (> 20–30 mEq/L). Given the severity of this patient's hyponatremia, she should be treated with restriction of oral fluids and administration of hypertonic saline. The correction of hyponatremia should be gradual (maximum increase of 10–12 mmol/L within 24 hours, or 0.5 mmol/L/hour) and under ICU observation, as rapid correction can lead to central pontine myelinolysis. In patients with SIADH and severe hyponatremia, the use of vasopressin receptor antagonists such as tolvaptan may be considered if serum sodium either continues to drop or fails to rise by 2 mmol/L after 24 hours.
Image Description:

FENa: fractional excretion of sodium
SIADH: syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
TURP: transurethral resection of the prostate
UNa: urine sodium
UOsm: urine osmolality

C) INCORRECT:

Opioids such as oxycodone can cause sedation, confusion, nausea, and vomiting in postoperative patients, even at normally prescribed doses. However, patients with an opioid overdose present with miosis and respiratory depression. This patient has a normal respiratory rate, is not hypoxemic, and does not have pinpoint pupils on examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary polydipsia (psychogenic polydipsia) leads to euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia, as seen here. However, this patient does not complain of excessive thirst, and there is no history of the patient drinking unusual amounts of water. Moreover, patients with primary polydipsia and hyponatremia have decreased urine sodium levels (< 20–30 mEq/L) and a urine osmolality less than 100 mOsmol/kg (maximally diluted urine).

E) INCORRECT:

Mineralocorticoid deficiency (hypoaldosteronism) would result in hyponatremia with decreased serum osmolality (hypotonic hyponatremia) and urine sodium levels > 20–30 mEq/L. However, patients present with signs of hypovolemia (e.g., hypotension, tachycardia), hyperkalemia, and a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis. This patient has a normal K+ level and is euvolemic.
questions.hint: Serum osmolality and volume status are important for differentiating the etiology of hyponatremia. This patient's serum osmolality is low (hypotonic) and she does not have edema or signs of hypovolemia, making her euvolemic. Euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia in the context of recent neurosurgery is suggestive of a specific underlying condition.

questions.text:
Two days after being admitted to the hospital following a fall, a 77-year-old woman reports fatigue and headaches. During the fall she sustained a right-sided subdural hematoma. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Her medications prior to admission were enalapril and atorvastatin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurologic examinations show no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



 Na+

130 mEq/L


 K+

4.0 mEq/L


 Cl-

103 mEq/L


 HCO3-

24 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
14 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 Osmolality
270 mOsmol/kg H2O


Urine



 Osmolality
326 mOsmol/kg H2O


A CT scan of the head shows an unchanged right-sided subdural hematoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Head elevation, as well as avoiding neck flexion/rotation or circumstances that may provoke Valsalva responses, are important actions to take when dealing with elevated intracranial pressure (ICP). This woman's history of head trauma is concerning for elevated ICP, especially since a subdural hematoma was noted on admission. With new-onset headache, further evaluation of the hematoma is necessary. However, since it appears to be stable and she is hyponatremic, this particular intervention is unlikely to provide relief of her symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Demeclocycline, a tetracycline, is helpful in treating SIADH because it acts as an antagonist to antidiuretic hormone within the kidney. However, this therapy is reserved for symptomatic patients, or when initial interventions fail to correct hyponatremia.

C) INCORRECT:

Tolvaptan is a vasopressin receptor antagonist, which makes it a useful drug for treating SIADH. This therapy is reserved for symptomatic patients, or when multiple interventions fail to correct hyponatremia.

D) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin is a synthetic vasopressin (i.e., antidiuretic hormone) analog used to treat central diabetes insipidus. Increasing antidiuretic hormone in this woman would make her hyponatremia worse.

E) CORRECT:

Fluid restriction is the first-line treatment for nonsevere, nonacute hyponatremia associated with SIADH. Intake of fluids must be decreased to the point where excretion of free water is greater than the intake of free water. A negative water balance reverses the dilutional hyponatremia that resulted from water retention induced by antidiuretic hormone. If fluid restriction fails to adequately increase serum sodium levels, pharmacological therapy with vasopressin receptor antagonists (e.g., tolvaptan) is indicated.

In patients with acute hyponatremia and/or severely symptomatic hyponatremia (e.g., altered mental state), hypertonic saline should be administered immediately.

F) INCORRECT:

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used to treat cerebral edema, elevated intracranial pressure, and acute angle-closure glaucoma. It acts to pull water into the nephron and reverse the dilutional hyponatremia. However, it causes large increases in urine output that can lead to dehydration and hypernatremia if not monitored closely. Mannitol is not used in the treatment of SIADH.

G) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic saline is used for hyponatremia with severe symptoms (e.g., seizures, altered mental status, coma), which can be seen in some cases of SIADH. Because this patient's symptoms are mild (e.g., headaches, fatigue), another treatment should be tried first.
questions.hint: This patient has mild hyponatremia and her urine is more concentrated than her blood. These findings in a patient with recent head trauma are suggestive of syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH).

questions.text: A 75-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of worsening shortness of breath when lying down and lower leg swelling. He has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, and myocardial infarction that developed 10 years ago. Current medications include metoprolol, lisinopril, ethacrynic acid, eplerenone, and aspirin. He drinks one beer daily. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history. He is allergic to sulfonamides. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention and 3+ pitting edema of the lower extremities. Crackles are heard over the lower lung fields bilaterally. The point of maximal impulse is palpated 2 cm to the left of the midclavicular line at the 6th intercostal space. Which of the following additional findings is most strongly associated with increased mortality?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with CHF, low levels of brain natriuretic peptide are associated with a good prognosis. High BNP levels are associated with a poor prognosis.

B) CORRECT:

Under normal conditions, ADH secretion is tightly controlled by serum osmolality. But in patients with CHF, nonosmotic stimuli for ADH secretion (e.g., increased baroreceptor firing) become more relevant, and ADH secretion increases due to the decrease in cardiac output (CO). Increased ADH leads to increased reabsorption of free water, which, in turn, results in hyponatremia due to fluid dilution in the extracellular fluid compartment. A decrease in serum sodium is therefore closely associated with a decrease in CO in patients with heart failure.

Both diuretics and ACE inhibitors can cause hyponatremia but they are still recommended for patients with CHF because they increase free water elimination and improve cardiac function.

C) INCORRECT:

A narrow QRS complex (shorter than 120 ms) is a normal finding that is not associated with a poor prognosis. In patients with CHF, a wide QRS complex (> 120 ms) is associated with a poor prognosis because it indicates left and/or right bundle branch block, and the greater the duration of the QRS complex, the lower the left ventricular ejection fraction.

D) INCORRECT:

A decreased VO2 indicates a poor prognosis because it indicates poor cardiopulmonary reserves. Increased VO2 levels would not be expected in patients with CHF.

E) INCORRECT:

A high cardiac index is associated with a good prognosis in patients with CHF.

F) INCORRECT:

In patients with CHF, decreased beat-to-beat variation in heart rate (not increased) is associated with a poor prognosis because it signifies sympathetic overactivity.
questions.hint: This patient has signs and symptoms of congestive heart failure (CHF), which can result in increased fluid retention. An increase in fluid retention is associated with a poor prognosis.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. On arrival, he has left hip and left leg pain. His pulse is 135/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 90/40 mm Hg. Examination shows an open left tibial fracture with active bleeding. The left lower extremity appears shortened, flexed, and internally rotated. Femoral and pedal pulses are decreased bilaterally. Massive transfusion protocol is initiated. An x-ray of the pelvis shows an open pelvic fracture and an open left tibial mid-shaft fracture. A CT scan of the head shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
10,000/mm3



Platelet count
250,000/mm3



Prothrombin time
12 sec


Partial thromboplastin time
30 sec


Serum



 Na+

125 mEq/L


 K+

4.5 mEq/L


 Cl-

98 mEq/L


 HCO3-

25 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
18 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL


The patient is taken emergently to interventional radiology for exploratory angiography and arterial embolization. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In response to renal hypoperfusion, as in this patient with massive blood loss, the kidneys release renin, which ultimately induces physiologic secretion of aldosterone through the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This increases renal reabsorption of both sodium and water to help maintain blood volume. Serum sodium levels do not typically change because of the concurrent reabsorption of sodium and water.

B) INCORRECT:

Pathologic aldosterone secretion occurs in primary hyperaldosteronism, which occurs secondary to adrenal hyperplasia or adrenal adenoma and would be an unlikely coincidental finding given this patient's acute presentation after a motor vehicle collision. Moreover, high systemic aldosterone levels increase renal reabsorption of both sodium and water; serum sodium levels are therefore typically normal. Other typical laboratory findings include hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, which this patient does not have. Clinical features include hypertension and features of hypokalemia, including fatigue, muscle weakness, and headache.

C) INCORRECT:

Adrenal crisis can occur after trauma in a patient with underlying adrenal insufficiency and can cause hypotension and hyponatremia. However, adrenal crisis also typically manifests with other electrolyte abnormalities, including hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis. Other clinical features include vomiting, severe abdominal pain, and hypoglycemia.

D) INCORRECT:

Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) can occur in the setting of cerebral trauma. Although it is possible that this patient sustained head trauma during the motor vehicle collision, another explanation for this patient's hyponatremia is more likely.

E) CORRECT:

A decrease in effective arterial blood volume (e.g., after massive blood loss) results in decreased baroreceptor firing. This leads to compensatory secretion of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which increases renal reabsorption of free water, thereby diluting serum sodium levels and causing hyponatremia. Management of hypovolemic hyponatremia includes volume repletion with normal saline. Correction of hypovolemia results in decreased ADH secretion, which increases free water excretion by the kidneys, leading to correction of serum sodium levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Renal hypoperfusion can cause acute kidney injury, including the renal tubules, which may lead to electrolyte derangements and is a plausible concern in a patient with massive blood loss. However, laboratory values would typically show multiple abnormalities, including hyperkalemia and increases in serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen.
questions.hint: Hyponatremia that develops after massive hemorrhage is likely dilutional.

questions.text:
A 77-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by her son for confusion for the last 7 days. The patient says she has had nausea and fatigue for the last week but is unable to provide a detailed history. She has Alzheimer disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which she takes metformin and sitagliptin. She lives alone and cares for herself, but her son says she frequently forgets to take her medications. She is lethargic but oriented to place. Her pulse is 85/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes. Urinalysis shows 2+ glucose and no ketones. Serum beta-hydroxybutyrate is negative. Results of laboratory studies are most likely to show which of the following?



Serum glucose (mg/dL)
Serum osmolality (mOsm/kg)
Serum sodium (mEq/L)
Serum bicarbonate (mEq/L)



A
820
325
132
22


B
400
305
132
15


C
650
330
148
25


D
400
272
132
28


E
150
285
150
22
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients with HHS typically present with marked hyperglycemia (serum glucose ≥ 600 mg/dL), which in turn causes increased serum osmolality (usually > 320 mOsm/kg). There is usually negligible ketone formation, due to the presence of endogenous insulin (as compared to DKA, where there is no endogenous insulin and so ketones are formed). Sodium levels are usually low, due to extracellular water shifts from the hyperosmolarity (hypertonic hyponatremia). While bicarbonate is consumed rapidly in diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), individuals with HHS often present with normal or only mildly decreased serum bicarbonate levels (usually ≥ 15 mEq/L). Treatment of patients with HHS consists of aggressive IV electrolyte and fluid replacement, as well as insulin for hyperglycemia

See “Diagnostic criteria for DKA and HHS” table.

B) INCORRECT:

This combination is consistent with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which causes hyperglycemia (but serum glucose usually remains < 600 mg/dL), decreased serum bicarbonate levels (usually < 18 mEq/L), normal or mildly increased serum osmolality (usually < 320 mOsm/kg), and low or normal serum sodium (due to hypertonic hyponatremia). While this patient's altered mental status and dehydration are consistent with DKA, the absence of ketones in both the urine and serum make this very unlikely. She also lacks other typical features of DKA, such as a rapid onset of symptoms and hyperventilation (Kussmaul respirations).

C) INCORRECT:

While this combination of hyperglycemia and hyperosmolarity is otherwise consistent with the patient's presentation of HHS, the sodium level is not consistent with her presentation. Corrected for her hyperglycemia, the sodium level would be approximately 157 mg/dL (measured sodium + 0.016*[serum glucose-100]), and at that level severe neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizure, coma) would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

The combination of low osmolarity and low sodium level indicates either decreased intravascular volume (hypovolemic hypotonic hyponatremia), and/or increased levels of ADH (e.g., due to SIADH), and is not consistent with this patient's presentation of HHS. This patient doesn't have any reported history of diarrhea and/or vomiting to suggest an etiology for hypovolemic hyponatremia. Additionally, her increased serum glucose (which is expected given the presence of severe glucosuria) should cause an increase in serum osmolarity, unlike the low osmolarity seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

This combination of hypernatremia and increased serum osmolarity would be consistent with dehydration from unreplaced water losses (e.g., from diarrhea, insensible losses, etc), which can present similarly to this patient (dry mucous membranes, fatigue, confusion). However, the normal glucose seen here is not consistent with the presence of severe glucosuria in this patient, and does not fit with the diagnosis of HHS.
questions.hint: This patient has glucosuria without evidence for ketone formation (negative urine ketone and serum beta-hydroxybutyrate), as well as signs of dehydration (dry mucous membranes), all of which suggest a diagnosis of hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS), likely due to poor compliance with her medication. The symptoms of HHS develop insidiously over several days.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife 20 minutes after she witnessed him vigorously shaking for about 1 minute. During this episode, he urinated on himself. He feels drowsy and has nausea. He has a history of chronic alcohol use disorder; he has been drinking 15 beers daily for the past 3 days. Before this time, he drank 8 beers daily. His last drink was 2 hours ago. He appears lethargic. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. On mental status examination, he is confused and not oriented to time. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
44%


Leukocyte count
12,000/mm3



Platelet count
320,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

112 mEq/L


 Cl-

75 mEq/L


 K+

3.8 mEq/L


 HCO3-

13 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
6 mEq/L


 Creatinine
0.6 mg/dL


 Albumin
2.1 g/dL


 Glucose
80 mg/dL


Urgent treatment for this patient's current condition puts him at increased risk for which of the following adverse events?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebral edema can develop as a complication of overly rapid correction of hypernatremia, not hyponatremia, as seen in this patient. Chronic hypernatremia causes an expansion of the intravascular volume; when sodium levels are acutely decreased, fluid shifts to the extravascular space causing brain swelling and edema, which can result in seizures, and at times, permanent neurologic deficits and death. As such, it is recommended that sodium levels be decreased by no more than 12 mEq/L per day.
Image Description:

Osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS): caused by rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia or severe acute hypernatremia; this hyperosmolar state pulls water out of brain cells, leading to demyelination, presenting as central pontine or extrapontine myelinolysis.

Cerebral edema: caused by rapid correction of chronic hypernatremia or severe acute hyponatremia; this hypo-osmolar state pushes water into brain cells, causing swelling, increased intracranial pressure, and potentially fatal transtentorial herniation.

B) INCORRECT:

Respiratory depression in the setting of alcohol abuse would be seen in patients in which benzodiazepines are given to prevent alcohol withdrawal syndrome. While this patient presented after a seizure (vigorously shaking for about 1 minute, urinated on himself), which can be seen in alcohol withdrawal syndrome, he has no features of ongoing withdrawal such as anxiety, palpitations, sweating, and autonomic hyperactivity. Additionally, withdrawal manifestations typically develop after six hours from the last alcoholic beverage, this patient's last drink was two hours ago, making this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac arrhythmias are unlikely to develop from excess sodium correction. Arrhythmias can happen in extreme cases of hypernatremia (Na+ > 190 mmol/L), but it is a rare complication of rapid correction of hyponatremia. Potassium fluctuations, on the other hand, are associated with an increased risk of arrhythmias. This patient's vital signs and potassium are within normal limits, making a cardiac condition unlikely to be the cause of his presentation.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperglycemia can be seen in patients given dextrose-containing intravenous fluids at a rapid rate for correction of hypernatremia. This patient, however, will likely be treated with hypertonic saline given his sodium level of 112 mmol/L.

E) CORRECT:

Osmotic myelinolysis (or osmotic demyelination syndrome; ODS) is a severe complication of rapid correction of hyponatremia that is characterized by damage to the myelin sheath of the white matter in the CNS. A sudden rise in blood osmolarity results in increased movement of fluid from the interstitial cerebral space to the intravascular compartment (to maintain an osmotic balance), which then causes myelin sheath edema and damage. Symptoms of ODS appear 2–6 days after correction of hyponatremia and include an altered level of consciousness (e.g., coma), locked-in syndrome, signs of cranial nerve dysfunction (e.g., dysarthria, dysphagia, diplopia), and/or worsening quadriparesis.

This patient likely has chronic hyponatremia due to chronic heavy drinking (i.e., beer potomania), which causes chronic cerebral edema and therefore increases the risk of developing ODS. It is recommended that serum sodium levels in affected individuals be raised at a rate of 0.5–1 mEq/L per hour until a total sodium correction of 4 to 6 mEq/L has been achieved in 24 hours. Given this patient's severe symptoms, the increase should be achieved within 6 hours.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (axial section; T2-weighted)

A hyperintense signal in the central pons is visible (green overlay). This hyperintensity has a characteristic trident shape that is pathognomonic of central pontine myelinolysis (CPM), which predominantly affects the transverse pontine fibers and spares the corticospinal tracts. CPM is caused by the rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia.

F) INCORRECT:

Wernicke encephalopathy is an acute and reversible emergency caused by severe thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It is mainly seen in the context of alcohol abuse. While this patient has a history of chronic alcohol intake and is currently confused, he lacks other classic features of Wernicke encephalopathy such as ataxia and ophthalmoplegia, making this diagnosis unlikely. In patients with suspected Wernicke encephalopathy, thiamine should always be administered before glucose, as glucose increases thiamine demand and can worsen encephalopathy.
questions.hint: Nausea, confusion, lethargy, seizure, and a sodium level of < 120 mEq/L are consistent with severely symptomatic hyponatremia, which requires prompt administration of intravenous hypertonic saline.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 1-day history of progressive confusion. He recently lost his job. He has a history of chronic alcoholism and has been drinking 14 beers daily for the past week. Before this time, he drank 6 beers daily. He appears lethargic. His vital signs are within normal limits. Serum studies show a sodium level of 111 mEq/L and a potassium level of 3.7 mEq/L. Urgent treatment for this patient's current condition increases his risk for which of the following adverse events?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wernicke encephalopathy is an acute and reversible emergency caused by severe thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. It is mainly seen in the context of alcohol abuse. While this patient has a history of chronic alcohol intake and is currently confused, he lacks other classic features of Wernicke encephalopathy such as ataxia and ophthalmoplegia, making this diagnosis unlikely. In patients with suspected Wernicke encephalopathy, thiamine should always be administered before glucose, as glucose increases thiamine demand and can worsen encephalopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Cerebral edema can develop as a complication of overly rapid correction of hypernatremia, not hyponatremia, as seen in this patient. Chronic hypernatremia causes an expansion of the intravascular volume; when sodium levels are acutely decreased, fluid shifts to the extravascular space causing brain swelling and edema, which can result in seizures, and at times, permanent neurologic deficits and death. As such, it is recommended that sodium levels be decreased by 12 mEq/L per day.

C) INCORRECT:

Cardiac arrhythmias are unlikely to develop from excess sodium correction. Arrhythmias can happen in extreme cases of hypernatremia (Na+ > 190 mmol/l), but it is a rare complication of rapid correction of hyponatremia. Potassium fluctuations, on the other hand, are associated with increased risk of arrhythmias. This patient's vital signs and potassium are within normal limits, making a cardiac condition unlikely to be the cause of his presentation.

D) CORRECT:

Osmotic myelinolysis develops when there is damage to the myelin sheath of nerves in the CNS. It is caused by a sudden rise in the osmolarity of blood, which results in increased movement of fluid from the interstitial space of the brain to the intravascular compartment in order to maintain an osmotic balance. This patient likely has chronic hyponatremia due to his excess drinking (referred to as beer potomania), which causes chronic brain swelling. When sodium levels are increased too quickly, especially in patients with sodium levels < 120 meq/L, the fluid shift causes the brain to shrink and demyelinate. As such, it is recommended that serum sodium levels be raised by less than 6 to 8 meq/L within 24 hours, at a rate of 0.5–1 mEq/L per hour.
Image Description:

Osmotic demyelination syndrome (ODS): caused by rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia or severe acute hypernatremia; this hyperosmolar state pulls water out of brain cells, leading to demyelination, presenting as central pontine or extrapontine myelinolysis.

Cerebral edema: caused by rapid correction of chronic hypernatremia or severe acute hyponatremia; this hypo-osmolar state pushes water into brain cells, causing swelling, increased intracranial pressure, and potentially fatal transtentorial herniation.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperglycemia can be seen in patients given dextrose-containing intravenous fluids at a rapid rate for correction of hypernatremia. This patient, however, will likely be treated with hypertonic saline given his sodium levels of 111 mmol/l.

F) INCORRECT:

Respiratory depression in the setting of alcohol abuse would be seen in patients in which benzodiazepines are given to prevent alcohol withdrawal syndrome. However, this patient has no features of ongoing withdrawal such as anxiety, palpitations, sweating, and autonomic hyperactivity.
questions.hint: This patient has acutely symptomatic hyponatremia (confusion, lethargy), for which the appropriate treatment is administration of intravenous hypertonic saline.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician for increasing fatigue over the past 3 months. During this period, her appetite has decreased and she has lost 10 kg (22 Ib). She also reports decreased sexual desire. She has a history of type 1 diabetes. Her pulse is 105/min and blood pressure is 95/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows darkening of the skin and oral mucous membranes. Serum studies show:


Na+
130 mEq/L


K+
5.2 mEq/L


Glucose (fasting)
74 mg/dL


Which of the following changes to body fluid volume and osmolarity would most likely be expected?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A shows isotonic fluid loss from the ECF in which there is a decrease in ECF volume but no change in ECF osmolarity because there is an equal loss of fluid and solute. Therefore, there is no fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF. Isotonic fluid loss from the ECF is seen in secretory diarrhea and external hemorrhage.

B) INCORRECT:

B shows hypertonic fluid gain to the ECF, which causes increased osmolarity in the ECF. This increased osmolarity generates a fluid shift from the ICF to the ECF until ICF osmolarity becomes equal to ECF osmolarity. Ultimately, this results in a decrease in ICF volume and an increase in ECF volume. Hypertonic fluid gain to the ECF is seen with the infusion of hypertonic fluids (e.g., hypertonic saline, colloids).

C) CORRECT:

C shows hyperosmotic fluid loss from the ECF, in which solute loss is greater than volume loss, resulting in hypovolemic hyponatremia. This imbalance leads to decreased osmolarity in the ECF, generating a fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF, which results in increased ICF volume and decreased ICF osmolarity. This pattern is seen in adrenocortical insufficiency (e.g., Addison disease), in which the deficiency of aldosterone leads to increased excretion of Na+. Increased excretion of Na+ results in higher concentrations of free solute in the urine relative to the ECF (i.e., loss of more solute than free water). Other conditions associated with hypovolemic hyponatremia include excessive use of loop diuretics and 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

D shows hypoosmotic volume loss from the ECF (i.e., loss of free water), resulting in hypovolemic hypernatremia. The loss of free water from the ECF leads to an increase in ECF osmolarity, inducing a fluid shift from the ICF to the ECF. Ultimately, this causes a decrease in ICF volume and an increase in ICF osmolarity. Hypoosmotic volume loss from the ECF occurs in diabetes insipidus, severe dehydration, or as a result of excessive sweating.

E) INCORRECT:

E shows hypoosmotic fluid gain to the ECF, which causes a decrease in ECF osmolarity and an increase in ECF volume. Decreased ECF osmolarity generates a fluid shift from the ECF into the ICF until ICF osmolarity becomes equal to ECF osmolarity. This shift causes an increase in ICF volume and a decrease in ICF osmolarity. Hypoosmotic fluid gain to the ECF is seen with the infusion of hypotonic fluids (e.g., hypotonic saline), SIADH, primary polydipsia, and conditions that cause hypervolemic hyponatremia (e.g., congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome). In patients with intact compensatory mechanisms, activation of the RAAS-system and secretion of atrial natriuretic peptide limits ECF expansion, thereby preventing edema formation.
questions.hint: This patient's history of autoimmune disease, clinical features (fatigue, hyperpigmentation, decreased libido, reduced appetite, weight loss), and laboratory findings (hyponatremia, hyperkalemia) are consistent with Addison disease, which is associated with loss of hyperosmotic fluid.

Repeat laboratory studies confirm hyponatremia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Measure serum TSH and cortisol levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The fractional excretion of sodium should be determined in patients with hypotonic hyponatremia to assess whether the cause is renal or extrarenal. However, first, it is important to establish whether the patient has hypotonic, isotonic, or hypertonic hyponatremia.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic saline is indicated in severely symptomatic hyponatremia to increase serum sodium rapidly to prevent cerebral edema and brain herniation. Rapid sodium correction is unnecessary and potentially harmful in patients with nonsevere symptoms due to the risk of overcorrection and subsequent osmotic demyelination syndrome. Hyponatremia with nonsevere symptoms (usually chronic hyponatremia) requires a slow sodium correction rate.

C) CORRECT:

Assessing serum osmolality is the first step in evaluating confirmed hyponatremia to differentiate between hypotonic (low serum osmolality), hypertonic (high serum osmolality), and isotonic (normal serum osmolality) hyponatremia. Hypotonic hyponatremia is the most common type of hyponatremia. Further diagnostic evaluation of hypotonic hyponatremia includes assessing urine osmolality (to determine antidiuretic hormone activity), determining volume status (to assess whether antidiuretic hormone activity is appropriate), and assessing urinary sodium and/or fractional excretion of sodium (to determine if the cause is renal or extrarenal).

This patient likely has hypotonic hyponatremia caused by SIADH following SSRI initiation.
Image Description:

FENa: fractional excretion of sodium
SIADH: syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
TURP: transurethral resection of the prostate
UNa: urine sodium
UOsm: urine osmolality

D) INCORRECT:

Measuring serum TSH and cortisol levels may be appropriate later in the workup as both hypothyroidism and hypocortisolism can manifest with hyponatremia. A different diagnostic study is more appropriate at this stage.

E) INCORRECT:

Furosemide may be considered for the management of hypervolemic hyponatremia. This patient does not have symptoms of hypervolemia (e.g., ascites, edema) or features of conditions that cause hypervolemic hyponatremia like congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, or renal failure with low urine output. Hyponatremia in this patient likely resulted from SIADH (triggered by SSRI initiation), which typically manifests with euvolemic hyponatremia. Additional diagnostics are required to inform further management.
questions.hint: After excluding hyperglycemia, additional management depends on an important first step in evaluating confirmed hyponatremia.

What are the patient's anion gap and corrected serum sodium level?

choices.text: The anion gap is 29; the corrected sodium level is 131 mEq/liter
The anion gap is 25; the corrected sodium level is 131 mEq/liter
The anion gap is 21; the corrected sodium level is 135 mEq/liter
The anion gap is 29; the corrected sodium level is 135 mEq/liter
The anion gap is 21; the corrected sodium level is 131 mEq/liter

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

To calculate the anion gap, the chloride and bicarbonate levels are subtracted from the uncorrected (measured) sodium level. In the present scenario, the anion gap is 127 - 92 - 14, which equals 21.

The corrected sodium level is calculated by adding 1.6 mEq/liter to the measured sodium level for every 100-mg/dL increase in the glucose level above a level of 100 mg/dL. In this scenario, the corrected sodium level is 127 + (1.6 × 5), which equals 135.

B) INCORRECT:

To calculate the anion gap, the chloride and bicarbonate levels are subtracted from the uncorrected (measured) sodium level. In the present scenario, the anion gap is 127 - 92 - 14, which equals 21.

The corrected sodium level is calculated by adding 1.6 mEq/liter to the measured sodium level for every 100-mg/dL increase in the glucose level above a level of 100 mg/dL. In this scenario, the corrected sodium level is 127 + (1.6 × 5), which equals 135.

C) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis of a metabolic acidosis can be narrowed by calculating the anion gap. The anion gap is the sum of negative unmeasured charges (negatively charged phosphates, sulfates, organic acids, and plasma proteins including albumin).

To calculate the anion gap, the chloride and bicarbonate levels are subtracted from the uncorrected (measured) sodium level. (Because the serum potassium fluctuates from other causes that are unrelated to acid/base derangements, the serum potassium is not ordinarily used to calculate the anion gap.) In the present scenario, the anion gap is 127 - 92 - 14, which equals 21. The corrected sodium level, which depends on a patient's glucose level, is not used to calculate the anion gap. This is because glucose is electrically neutral and therefore does not affect the anion gap. The serum albumin level is normal (4 g/dL); therefore, no correction is required for this negatively charged plasma protein. Low serum albumin would decrease the anion gap; in that situation, it would be necessary to add 2.5 to the anion gap for every 1-g/dL decrease in serum albumin below the normal value of 4 g/dL.

The corrected sodium level is calculated by adding 1.6 mEq/liter to the measured sodium level for every 100-mg/dL increase in the glucose level above a level of 100 mg/dL. In this scenario, the corrected sodium level is 127 + (1.6 × 5), which equals 135.

Key learning point: To calculate a patient’s anion gap, subtract the chloride and bicarbonate levels from the uncorrected sodium level.

D) INCORRECT:

To calculate the anion gap, the chloride and bicarbonate levels are subtracted from the uncorrected (measured) sodium level. In the present scenario, the anion gap is 127 - 92 - 14, which equals 21.

The corrected sodium level is calculated by adding 1.6 mEq/liter to the measured sodium level for every 100-mg/dL increase in the glucose level above a level of 100 mg/dL. In this scenario, the corrected sodium level is 127 + (1.6 × 5), which equals 135.

E) INCORRECT:

To calculate the anion gap, the chloride and bicarbonate levels are subtracted from the uncorrected (measured) sodium level. In the present scenario, the anion gap is 127 - 92 - 14, which equals 21.

The corrected sodium level is calculated by adding 1.6 mEq/liter to the measured sodium level for every 100-mg/dL increase in the glucose level above a level of 100 mg/dL. In this scenario, the corrected sodium level is 127 + (1.6 × 5), which equals 135.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the emergency department (ED) 10 days after transsphenoidal resection of a 3.8-cm suprasellar mass that was detected on MRI after temporal visual-field defects were found on routine eye examination. Preoperative evaluation revealed normal chemistries, normal thyroxine and cortisol levels, a prolactin level of 36 ng/mL (reference range, 0–20), and inappropriately low gonadotropin levels.
After surgery, the patient experienced gradual restoration of her visual fields. On postoperative laboratory evaluation, her complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, cortisol and free thyroxine levels were all normal. Today, the patient presents to the ED with generalized weakness. Her blood pressure and heart rate are within normal limits. Her mucous membranes are moist, and she has no peripheral edema. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Follow-up laboratory testing, conducted at 8 a.m., yields the following results:

Which one of the following treatments is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Conivaptan is an intravenous vasopressin-receptor antagonist that is approved for treating euvolemic hyponatremia. It is not indicated in a patient who is recovering from pituitary surgery, given that the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone is usually transient in this setting, and the hyponatremia is not severe.

B) INCORRECT:

Desmopressin, a synthetic form of antidiuretic hormone, is used to treat central diabetes insipidus, which is another possible complication of transsphenoidal surgery. However, central diabetes insipidus is characterized by polyuria, polydipsia and, typically, an elevated serum sodium level.

C) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is indicated in hypervolemic hyponatremia, such as that due to congestive heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Adrenal insufficiency and central hypothyroidism are excluded by the finding of normal cortisol and free thyroxine levels, respectively, so replacement with hydrocortisone and levothyroxine would be ineffective.

E) CORRECT:

Hyponatremia that occurs approximately 7 to 10 days after transsphenoidal surgery points to a diagnosis of the syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH), which is a known late complication of transsphenoidal surgery. SIADH is usually transient, and the treatment is daily fluid restriction.

Key learning point: Hyponatremia that develops one week after transsphenoidal surgery in a patient with normal cortisol levels and normal thyroid function should prompt consideration of a diagnosis of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman is evaluated for polyuria one day after transsphenoidal pituitary surgery to resect a nonfunctional pituitary adenoma (2 cm in diameter). She has had a urine output of approximately 400 or 500 mL/hour for the past 4 hours and is very thirsty. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and normal visual fields.
Laboratory testing shows a serum sodium level of 147 mEq/liter (reference range, 136–145), a blood glucose level of 105 mg/dL (70–100), and a urine specific gravity of 1.001 (1.001–1.035).
What treatment is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic (3%) saline would not be appropriate treatment for a patient with hypernatremia.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are treatments for adrenal insufficiency. Although patients are at risk for central adrenal insufficiency after pituitary surgery, there is usually no indication to give hydrocortisone preemptively; it is given only if the patient is found to have adrenal insufficiency on routine postoperative blood testing. There is no role for fludrocortisone with central adrenal insufficiency; it is used in primary adrenal insufficiency when there is also mineralocorticoid deficiency.

C) INCORRECT:

Demeclocycline is used for the treatment of patients with the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, which is characterized by hyponatremia.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are treatments for adrenal insufficiency. Although patients are at risk for central adrenal insufficiency after pituitary surgery, there is usually no indication to give hydrocortisone preemptively; it is given only if the patient is found to have adrenal insufficiency on routine postoperative blood testing. There is no role for fludrocortisone with central adrenal insufficiency; it is used in primary adrenal insufficiency when there is also mineralocorticoid deficiency.

E) CORRECT:

Patients who undergo transsphenoidal pituitary surgery are at risk for central diabetes insipidus. Surgery can disrupt the hypothalamus, stalk, and posterior pituitary, leading to a block in the release of vasopressin. The symptoms of diabetes insipidus tend to develop within the first 48 hours after surgery.

In diabetes insipidus, the inability to appropriately concentrate urine results in polyuria (urinary excretion >2.5 mL/kg/hour). In addition to polyuria, diabetes insipidus is diagnosed by a combination of symptoms and laboratory findings including dilute urine, polydipsia, dehydration, a high serum sodium level, low urine osmolality, and high serum osmolality.

Patients with diabetes insipidus should be treated with vasopressin. Vasopressin acts on receptors in the kidney to modulate water reabsorption.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient who has low urine osmolality, hypernatremia, and high serum osmolality one day after pituitary surgery is vasopressin.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents in the emergency department for evaluation of weakness, fatigue, and inability to concentrate. She has no significant medical, surgical, social, or family history and takes no medications. She notes that she started a weight-loss diet one week ago that consists entirely of pineapple, toast, and increased hydration with water and diet soda. She has been drinking approximately 4 liters of water or diet soda per day since she started the diet.
She has a blood pressure of 117/82 mm Hg, a heart rate of 95 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and a temperature of 37.1°C. Her weight is 84 kg (BMI, 29.1). Physical examination reveals normal skin turgor; no cyanosis, jaundice, or pallor; normal heart, lung, and abdominal findings; normal jugular venous pressure; and no edema. Neurologic examination is within normal limits.
Laboratory findings are as follows:

A urine pregnancy test is negative. Urine output is 900 mL over 4 hours.
What is the most likely cause of this patient’s hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient’s hyponatremia is a result of a low-solute diet combined with high fluid intake; this combination impairs the kidneys’ ability to excrete large volumes of water.

Total daily solute excretion is determined mostly by dietary solute intake; a normal adult with a usual diet consumes 5 to 10 mOsm per kg of body weight daily (about 600–900 mOsm/day). Consider the following equation:

Total daily solute excretion (mOsm) = urine weight (kg) × urine osmolality (mOsm/kg)

Given that one liter of urine weighs close to one kg, the urine volume (in liters) can be substituted for the urine weight in the above formula. If a patient had a typical diet with an intake of 600 mOsm/day but drank 6 liters of fluid per day, the urine osmolality would need to be 100 mOsm/kg for the kidneys to excrete the water. If the dietary solute load was only 300 mOsm/day, then the urine osmolality would need to be 50 mOsm/kg for the kidneys to excrete the water. If water intake increased further, the kidneys would not be able to excrete this excess water and hyponatremia would develop, because the kidneys cannot create urine that is more dilute than 50 mOsm/kg.

This patient's history suggests that she has had a very low-solute diet with minimal salt and no protein. Her urine is dilute, and her urine output is brisk. If she limits her fluid intake, she will excrete the excess water, and her serum sodium level will steadily improve.

This clinical scenario of hyponatremia from high-fluid/low-solute intake has been referred to as beer potomania when it occurs in beer drinkers with a low-solute diet. This phenomenon is also commonly observed in older patients with a low-solute diet that some refer to as the “tea and toast” diet.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of hyponatremia in a euvolemic, hypo-osmolar, hyponatremic patient with a low urine sodium level and low urine osmolality is a low-solute diet.

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetes insipidus (DI) is caused by either low ADH levels (as with central DI) or ADH resistance in the kidneys (as with nephrogenic DI). The urine is dilute and there is polyuria, as in this case, but patients develop hypernatremia rather than hyponatremia.

C) INCORRECT:

Reset osmostat is a term used to describe mild, asymptomatic hyponatremia that is stable on multiple measurements. Individuals with reset osmostat have dilute urine after water ingestion and concentrated urine with water restriction.

D) INCORRECT:

The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) is also characterized by hyponatremia. However, in SIADH, elevated ADH levels lead to a small volume of concentrated urine. This patient has brisk output of dilute urine; the kidneys' response to the hyponatremia appears to be appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Cerebral salt wasting syndrome occurs after an inciting event within the central nervous system (particularly subarachnoid hemorrhage) or a neurosurgical procedure and causes hypovolemic hypotonic hyponatremia. This patient has euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia and does not have any risk factors for cerebral salt wasting syndrome.

questions.text:

He quit smoking 10 years ago and has a 35-pack-year history. He regularly uses albuterol and ipratropium metered-dose inhalers but takes no other medications.
His temperature is 36.5°C, his blood pressure is 140/74 mm Hg, his heart rate is 89 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. He weighs 81.6 kg (BMI, 24.4). The urine sodium level is 62 mEq/liter (varies with intake), and the urine osmolality is 528 mOsm/kg (varies with intake).
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s hyponatremia?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Volume depletion would be unlikely in a patient who has a normal volume status on physical examination, no reported history of volume loss or inadequate fluid intake, and a urine sodium level that is not low.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has hyponatremia. His measured serum osmolality is also low, which excludes the possibility of pseudohyponatremia from a laboratory error and also the possibility of hyperosmolar hyponatremia, which can be seen with hyperglycemia. He does not have a history of volume loss or inadequate fluid intake. On physical examination, he is euvolemic. His urine sodium level is not low, which suggests that the kidneys are not sodium-avid and that the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis is not activated. However, the urine is very concentrated, and this finding is consistent with antidiuretic hormone (ADH) activity. Given the patient's hypo-osmolar state and lack of volume depletion, this secretion of ADH is inappropriate.

SIADH has many causes, but in a patient with a history of cigarette smoking, the possibility of paraneoplastic SIADH from small-cell lung cancer should be considered. Chest imaging would be the first step in evaluating the cause of SIADH in a patient with a history of cigarette smoking.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of euvolemic hypotonic hyponatremia in a former smoker with an inability to dilute urine is paraneoplastic syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.

C) INCORRECT:

SIADH can occur in the setting of severe hypothyroidism, but this patient’s thyroid-stimulating hormone level is within normal range, making this an unlikely cause of SIADH. Similarly, adrenal insufficiency can cause the laboratory findings seen in this case and should be excluded with a morning cortisol before the diagnosis of SIADH can be confirmed.

D) INCORRECT:

Cerebral salt wasting syndrome is characterized by evidence of volume depletion on physical examination. This disorder is extremely rare but can be seen following brain injury or surgery.

E) INCORRECT:

In cases of hyponatremia caused by polydipsia, urine osmolality is usually dilute, <100 mOsm/kg (much lower than this patient’s value); the urinary sodium level may also be low because of dilution.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hypothyroidism, systemic lupus erythematosus, adrenal insufficiency, osteopenia, and depression presents to the emergency department (ED) with acute onset of nausea and vomiting for 12 hours. She reports lightheadedness, especially when standing. Her medications include amlodipine 5 mg daily, chlorthalidone 12.5 mg daily, levothyroxine 125 μg daily, hydrocortisone 15 mg in the morning and 5 mg in the evening, fludrocortisone 0.05 mg 5 days per week, calcium carbonate 500 mg twice daily, and citalopram 10 mg daily.
When the patient is supine, her blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 90 beats per minute. When she sits up, her blood pressure decreases to 100/60 mm Hg, and her heart rate increases to 125 beats per minute. Her mucous membranes appear dry, and her lungs are clear bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal, there is no jugular venous distention, and her extremities show no edema. A chest radiograph performed in the ED shows a 1.2-cm nodule in the right upper lung field that was not present on images obtained 18 months ago.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range

In addition to holding the chlorthalidone and calcium supplement, providing stress doses of glucocorticoids, and serially reassessing the patient’s clinical condition and laboratory parameters, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for immediate management?

choices.text: Administer 4 mg of zoledronic acid intravenously
Administer 100 mL of 3% sodium chloride intravenously
Administer 1 liter of 0.9% sodium chloride intravenously

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s hypercalcemia is of unclear etiology at this point but may be related to the possible malignancy seen on chest radiography. The best initial management of hypercalcemia is intravenous fluids such as 0.9% sodium chloride. This may be sufficient to normalize the calcium; therefore, administering zoledronic acid would be premature at this point. In addition, the patient has renal dysfunction, which is a relative contraindication to bisphosphonate therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypertonic (3%) saline can be used in patients with moderate hyponatremia (sodium, 120–129 mEq/liter) or severe hyponatremia (sodium, <120 mEq/liter) who have severe symptoms of hyponatremia (such as altered mental status). It can also be used in patients with severe hyponatremia and moderate symptoms (such as nausea and vomiting or malaise). However, this patient has moderate hyponatremia and only moderate symptoms; thus, the risk of correcting too quickly or too much outweighs the benefit in this case. Correcting the volume is a better first step.

C) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics, such as furosemide, interfere with the kidneys’ ability to maximally concentrate the urine by diluting the medullary gradient. Therefore, loop diuretics can help in the management of SIADH by causing a more dilute urine and improved excretion of excess free water. However, loop diuretics would not be an appropriate immediate strategy for a patient with evidence of volume depletion. Both types of diuretics can lead to hyponatremia if volume depletion develops and then the patient drinks significant amount of fluids. Loop diuretics have been used for the management of hypercalcemia and previously were touted to increase urinary calcium loss by interfering with reabsorption in the loop of Henle. Although this principle has been challenged, furosemide can still be helpful in patients with hypercalcemia who have volume overload.

D) INCORRECT:

There are several potential etiologies for this patient’s nausea, vomiting, and lightheadedness. She may have adrenal insufficiency, or her symptoms may be related to her hypercalcemia and hyponatremia. In any patient who presents with a history of adrenal insufficiency and new intercurrent illness, it is reasonable to increase the dose of the glucocorticoid (stress dose). However, the dose of the mineralocorticoid (fludrocortisone) generally does not need to be increased; in fact, if a high dose of intravenous hydrocortisone is used for the stress dose of the glucocorticoid, then it provides sufficient mineralocorticoid activity itself, and the mineralocorticoid can be stopped for a few days.

E) CORRECT:

There are several potential etiologies for this patient’s nausea, vomiting, and lightheadedness. She may have adrenal insufficiency, or her symptoms may be related to her hypercalcemia and hyponatremia. In any patient who presents with a history of adrenal insufficiency and new intercurrent illness, it is reasonable to increase the dose of the glucocorticoid (stress dose). However, the dose of the mineralocorticoid (fludrocortisone) generally does not need to be increased; in fact, if a high dose of intravenous hydrocortisone is used for the stress dose of the glucocorticoid, then it provides sufficient mineralocorticoid activity itself, and the mineralocorticoid can be stopped for a few days. In addition to stress doses of glucocorticoids, intravenous fluids are also indicated in a patient with acutely symptomatic adrenal insufficiency.

This patient’s hypercalcemia is of unclear etiology at this point but may be related to the possible malignancy seen on chest radiography. The best initial management of hypercalcemia is intravenous fluids such as 0.9% sodium chloride.

Before starting intravenous fluids for the hypercalcemia and the adrenal insufficiency, the effects of this intervention on the patient’s hyponatremia should be considered. This patient’s history and physical examination findings suggest hypovolemia. Hypovolemia stimulates antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion, which will increase renal reabsorption of water and reduce urine volume. In addition, hypovolemia stimulates the sympathetic nervous system and the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis, leading to an increase in renal sodium reabsorption. In the setting of volume depletion, the urine osmolality should be very high and the urinary sodium very low, as is seen here. In this setting, if the patient ingests dilute fluids, hyponatremia will develop. When volume is restored in patients with hypovolemic hyponatremia, the stimulus for ADH is no longer present, and the kidneys are able to excrete the excess water. Thus, the most appropriate next step in this case is administration of 1 liter of 0.9% sodium chloride. It is worth noting, however, that patients with hypovolemic hyponatremia are at risk for rapid correction and require close monitoring.

ADH levels should rise in hypovolemia and hyperosmolality. When ADH levels are elevated without these two conditions, it is diagnostic of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). In SIADH, patients are euvolemic, but the inappropriate release of ADH leads to concentrated urine. If the patient ingests dilute fluids, hyponatremia develops. This patient has several risk factors for SIADH, including a lung lesion and use of a selective serotonin-reuptake inhibitor, but the clinical history of vomiting, physical examination finding of orthostatic tachycardia, and low urine sodium level suggest hypovolemia. Treatment for SIADH typically includes addressing the underlying cause and restricting fluid intake, with additional interventions to be considered if necessary.

Thiazide diuretics, including chlorthalidone, lead to hyponatremia more commonly than loop diuretics. Thiazide diuretics act in the distal convoluted tubule and interfere with the kidneys’ ability to maximally dilute the urine. As a result, the kidneys have more difficulty excreting a water load, which can lead to hyponatremia, particularly in individuals with other reasons for impaired water excretion, such as older individuals and those with lower solute intake. If this was the primary cause of this patient’s hyponatremia, then the urine sodium would not be low, and the urine osmolality would not be as high as it is.

Key learning point: In a patient with hypotonic hyponatremia associated with volume depletion, treatment should first be aimed at providing adequate fluid volume and establishing euvolemia.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for the second time this month with fatigue and muscle cramps. Her medical history includes chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, hypertension, and a recent diagnosis of limited-stage small-cell lung cancer. She is undergoing evaluation for surgical resection of the lung cancer. Her medications are lisinopril 20 mg daily, amlodipine 5 mg daily, and inhaled fluticasone and salmeterol.
Her blood pressure is 142/78 mm Hg, her heart rate is 80 beats per minute, and her respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute; she weighs 72 kg. Examination of the lungs reveals mild expiratory wheezes. Examination of the heart and abdomen is unremarkable, and there is no peripheral edema.
Laboratory results from the last admission and from today are as follows:
